thread.section_title: Business News, Economy, Finance & ASX Market News
thread.title: Asset sales top $6 billion in office market
thread.title_full: Asset sales top $6 billion in office market

title: Asset sales top $6 billion in office market
text:
Sydney's office market is tipped for more property sales.
The pending sale of the $7 billion Investa office platform is expected to trigger a fresh round of asset sales at time when investors are hungry for higher-yielding and less volatile bricks-and-mortar properties.
It has been suggested the overseas buyers – Blackstone, Brookfield and the Chinese Investment Corp – are the front runners for the management rights and a direct holding in the Investa Office Fund, which is being sold by Morgan Stanley.
Analysts say the end of the long-running sale is nearing, with details expected to emerge in the coming weeks before the start of the August reporting season.
The potential sale of interests in assets, such as 400 George Street, Sydney, come as commercial property in Sydney's CBD remains one of the most sought-after assets with record performances year on year.
Advertisement Savills recorded $5.8 billion of office transactions in the 12 months to June 2015, up 78 per cent from $3.34 billion in the previous 12 months, and up on the five-year average of $2.96 billion.
Savills research analyst Houssam Yakzan said this could turn out to be Sydney's strongest year of office investment.
Institutions, which consist of funds, real estate investment trusts and high-net-worth individual syndicates, were the most aggressive investors, purchasing $3.1 billion (or 54 per cent) in Sydney's CBD, closely followed by foreign investors taking home $2.4 billion.
Foreign investors have long been part of the commercial property scene but it is only in the past four years that we have seen such a rapid surge in demand, in particular from our Asian neighbours.
Two notable transactions included Dalian Wanda's purchase of One Golf Fields House for $425 million in December 2014 and more recently, Lend Lease One International Towers Sydney Trust attracted foreign investment as Qatar Investment Authority secured a 37.5 percent stake of the equity, about $525 million.
The Lendlease site at Circular Quay, worth as much as $1 billion, is said to be favoured by Cbus as a potential purchase.
The demand for the assets will be boosted by the falling supply, Knight Frank's latest report shows.
Knight Frank's head of research for Australia, Matt Whitby, says the major driver for the change of use of office stock has been the upswing in residential investment demand and the associated clamour for development sites.
Permanent withdrawals of office stock across major east coast CBD and fringe markets of Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane will accelerate 41 per cent in 2015 and then peak a further 48 per cent higher in 2016, according to Knight Frank's latest research.
The research report, titled Permanent Office Stock Withdrawals: Development Market Insight, July 2015, has found that the major east coast CBD and fringe markets will have 513,610 square metres of office stock permanently withdrawn between 2015 and 2018. There is also a further 296,292 square metres of potential withdrawal identified.
It says that in Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane, 47 per cent of the stock withdrawn from CBD and fringe markets is for a change of use to residential, with a further 26 per cent slated for a likely residential-hotel development and 7 per cent with pure hotel proposals.
Knight Frank head of institutional sales for Australia, James Parry, said most of the office stock withdrawal activity was happening in the Sydney market.
"This is essentially because of the lack of development sites in the CBD and immediate surrounds. With much of the current residential development further out in the fringe, there is a push for future development to be more concentrated in the central areas," Mr Parry said.
